title: Tanning salon posted pictures of golliwog and monkey emojis in online promotion
text:
The salon has apologised for using the offensive doll in its social posts (Picture: SWNS)

A tanning salon has been slammed for repeatedly using a golliwog and making black ‘jokes’ to promote its business on Facebook.

Shine Tanning Salon in Glasgow has now apologised for the ‘racist’ promotions, with the doll now widely considered to be racist, offensive and degrading.

Images of the doll first appeared on the salon’s Facebook page on Saturday when it was pictured with an empty coffee cup and the caption ‘wee black double espresso’ and two monkey emojis.

Another picture showed the doll – which the person posting had named ‘Sooty’ – lying next to a tanning bed and bottles of white2black tanning lotion.

The caption ‘#black2white’ had been used.

Golliwogs, featuring black skin, oversized lips, frizzy hair and paws instead of hands, are often associated with blackface and seen as a symbol of black oppression.

One of the pictures was captioned #black2white – a reference to tanning lotion

Although owning or selling golliwogs are not illegal in the UK, some people have been warned about possible prosecution for harassment for showing the dolls in public.

The tanning salon has apologised for its social media posts, saying they were ‘ill-thought’ and a ‘lazy attempt at humour’.

Anti-racism charity Show Racism The Red Card Scotland condemned sharing pictures of the ‘horrid’ item.

Jordan Allison, the charity’s campaign manager, said: ‘We stand with the rest of society who fully condemn these horrid items that serve only as offensive reminders of anti-Black racism.

‘Education remains key in ensuring these are consigned to history.

‘As anti-racist campaigners, we regularly work alongside Glasgow City Council and Police Scotland who are both very proactive in dealing with issues like these appropriately.’

Another picture with a coffee cup had been captioned ‘wee black double espresso’

A spokeswoman for the salon said the company made ‘no attempt to condone the posts’ and apologised to ‘anyone who was offended’.

They added: ‘Shine Tanning Salon is a multi-culture salon, owned by a family with Kenyan and Indian heritage, so is very aware of the effects of racism and casual racism in society.

‘Again, we can only reiterate that this was never our intention; it was a lazy attempt at humour, which we accept has caused people offence.

‘Shine Tanning Salon is very active in the local community, helping local residents back to work, and donating to charity; having donated 3 figure sums to SAMH and Breast Cancer Now this year already.

‘We hope that the Glasgow public, and wider audience who were offended by our posts will accept our apology; again, we make no excuses.’

They said the posts were ‘an error of judgement’ made by a staff member.

Images of the doll first appeared on the salon’s Facebook accounts on Saturday (Picture: SWNS)

The spokeswoman said: ‘We will be reaching out to relevant charities and organisations to seek literature to hand out to staff in relation to the effects racism can have and we will also be reviewing our social media policies.

‘Shine Tanning Salon will also be donating 20% of profits from the remainder of October to a relevant charity.

‘Whilst this by no means makes up for our actions, we hope that it goes a small way towards everyone affected accepting our apology.’
